Award.AbstractNarration:
The origin of ultrahigh energy cosmic rays (UHECRs) is one of the most puzzling questions in high energy particle astrophysics. Its solution may radically change our knowledge of the most extreme astrophysical objects in the Universe, of the magnetic fields which permeate it, or of particle physics. Several open questions remain - What is the origin of the observed features in the energy spectrum? What is the composition of the UHECRs? What are the sources of the UHECRs? In addition, UHECRs explore particle interactions at energies beyond the reach of current accelerators. Are particle interactions above 100 TeV center-of-mass energy what we expect?

This award provides funds for the continued participation of the U. Chicago group with the Pierre Auger Observatory (PAO) and related particle astrophysics. With its 3000 km-squared area, it is the largest cosmic ray detector ever built. Particle showers produced by UHECRs are detected at the ground by a sparse array of surface detectors (SD), and in the atmosphere by fluorescence detector (FD) telescopes sensitive to the light from nitrogen fluorescence excited by the shower particles. Since its completion in 2008, the PAO has unequivocally established a steep flux suppression at the end of the energy spectrum, found hints of anisotropies in the UHECRs arrival directions and indications of a heavier UHECR composition at the highest energies. This group will address these questions by improving Auger measurements (spectrum, anisotropy, composition, proton-air cross section) with better statistics and data analysis methods, and by providing phenomenological interpretations of the data.

Immersive research experiences, innovative detector laboratories, and partnerships with planetariums will bring UHECR science to formal and informal audiences. Research experiences developed in collaboration with programs focused on underrepresented groups, e.g. Fisk-Vanderbilt Bridge, will enhance diversity at the graduate and undergraduate levels. UHECR science will reach broad and diverse audiences through partnerships with the Auger Visitors Center, the Malargue Planetarium, the Adler Planetarium and videos. The Adler collaboration will include the high-impact Astronomy Conversations program, where scientists interact directly with museum visitors, exploring Spanish language programming, and developing a full dome UHECR show.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Pierre Auger Observatory, located in the province of Mendoza, Argentina, is the largest cosmic ray detector ever built. It covers an area of roughly the size of Rhode Island to detect ultra-high energy cosmic rays (UHECRs), extremely rare particles of energies up to ten million times greater than those reached by the Large Hadron Collider, the most powerful particle accelerator on earth. Their origin is a long-standing mystery in particle astrophysics, possibly linked to the most powerful astrophysical objects in the universe. By analyzing the data set steadily collected at the Observatory and through theoretical investigations, this project has significantly advanced the knowledge of UHECRs. Accurate measurements of the UHECRs’ energy spectrum and composition (i.e. whether they are protons or nuclei) have firmly established distinctive features, providing strong constraints to theories of the origin of UHECRs. An exotic explanation that UHECRs are new particles called magnetic monopoles was explored and found to be unlikely.  A major outcome of the project is the observation of anisotropy in the arrival direction of UHECRs, namely that their rate is greater from one side of the sky than the other, in a direction where the distribution of galaxies is relatively high. This result strongly suggests that UHECRs are produced outside our galaxy, an important piece of the puzzle to unveil the origin of UHECRs.  Another outcome of the project is the development of new techniques to detect UHECRs through the radiation (radio waves or UV light) emitted by the shower of secondary particles produced in the atmosphere by the UHECR interaction.  In particular a novel low-cost telescope was designed, built and installed; it has successfully detected UHECRs showers and is currently in data taking.  On the theoretical side, this project investigated potential astrophysical sites for cosmic-ray acceleration from very high energies to ultrahigh energies, including fast-spinning pulsars and clusters of galaxies.

This project has had lasting impact on the next generation of researchers, with special attention to diversity, and on the public, by bringing forefront research to thousands via planetarium partnerships. We have made a concerted effort to encourage minority and under-represented groups in STEM and to offer strong role models through programs as the “Summer Undergraduate Research Opportunities for Minorities and Women” at the University of Chicago and The Fisk-Vanderbilt Bridge program, which targets minority students of unrealized potential. At the undergraduate level, fifteen students conducted hands-on research in PI Privitera’s group (50% women or underrepresented minority). The two PhD students who graduated - one women and one minority - have successfully continued their career in research with postdoctoral fellowships. The “Astronomy Conversations”, a highly successful program of the Adler Planetarium where a scientist interacts directly with visitors in the Adler Space Visualizations Lab, answering questions and displaying data and visuals related to high energy astrophysics, reaches over a 1000s museum visitors. Visualizations tools  for detectors and UHECRs showers have been extensively used to engage audiences at Adler, at other planetaria, and at public talks.  Our researchers have participated to several high-impact public events – for example, Co-I Olinto brought her experience as a scientist to a group of over 100 young women in The Chicago Network Panel on Space, which was broadly featured in the media (e.g. “Young women learn that not even sky is limit in STEM careers”, February 26, 2016, Chicago Tribune.)
